tags.label: Historical Thinking Skill
tags.description: Historical Thinking Skill

tags.label: Skill Level 1
tags.description: Skill Level 1: Identify and Explain Historical Developments and Processes.

tags.label: Skill 1.A
tags.description: Skill 1.A: Identify a historical concept, development, or process.

tags.label: Skill 1.B
tags.description: Skill 1.B: Explain a historical concept, development, or process.

tags.label: Skill Level 2
tags.description: Skill Level 2: Analyze Primary and Secondary Sources of Historical Evidence.

tags.label: Skill 2.A
tags.description: Skill 2.A: Identify  a source's point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience.

tags.label: Skill 2.B
tags.description: Skill 2.B: Explain the point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience of a source.

tags.label: Skill 2.C
tags.description: Skill 2.C: Explain the significance of a source's point of view, purpose, historical situation, and/or audience, including how these might limit the use(s) of a source.

tags.label: Skill Level 3
tags.description: Skill Level 3: Analyze Arguments in Primary and Secondary Sources.

tags.label: Skill 3.A
tags.description: Skill 3.A: Identify and describe a claim and/or argument in a text-based or non-text-based source.

tags.label: Skill 3.B
tags.description: Skill 3.B: Identify the evidence used in a source to support an argument.

tags.label: Skill 3.C
tags.description: Skill 3.C: Compare the arguments or main ideas of two sources.

tags.label: Skill 3.D
tags.description: Skill 3.D: Explain how claims or evidence support, modify, or refute a source's argument.

tags.label: Skill Level 4
tags.description: Skill Level 4: Analyze the Context of Historical Events, Developments or Processes.

tags.label: Skill 4.A
tags.description: Skill 4.A: Identify and describe a historical context for a specific historical development or process.

tags.label: Skill 4.B
tags.description: Skill 4.B: Explain how a specific historical development or process is situated within a broader historical context.

tags.label: Skill Level 5
tags.description: Skill Level 5: Analyze Patterns and Connections Between and Among Historical Developments and Processes.

tags.label: Skill 5.A
tags.description: Skill 5.A: Identify patterns among or connections between historical developments and processes.

tags.label: Skill 5.B
tags.description: Skill 5.B: Explain how a historical development or process relates to another historical development or process.

tags.label: Skill Level 6
tags.description: Skill Level 6: Develop an Argument.

tags.label: Skill 6.A
tags.description: Skill 6.A: Make a historically defensible claim.

tags.label: Skill 6.B
tags.description: Skill 6.B: Support an argument using specific and relevant evidence.  a. Describe specific examples of historically relevant evidence.  b. Explain how specific examples of historically relevant evidence support an argument.

tags.label: Skill 6.C
tags.description: Skill 6.C: Use historical reasoning to explain relationships among pieces of historical evidence.

tags.label: Skill 6.D
tags.description: Skill 6.D: Corroborate, qualify, or modify an argument using diverse and alternative evidence in order to develop a complex argument. This argument might...

tags.label: Unit 1, Learning Objective A
tags.description: Unit 1, Learning Objective A: Explain the context for European encounters in the Americas from 1491 to 1607.

tags.label: Unit 1, Learning Objective B
tags.description: Unit 1, Learning Objective B: Explain how and why various native populations in the period before European contact interacted with the natural environment in North America.

tags.label: Unit 1, Learning Objective C
tags.description: Unit 1, Learning Objective C: Explain the causes of exploration and conquest of the New World by various European nations.

tags.label: Unit 1, Learning Objective D
tags.description: Unit 1, Learning Objective D: Explain causes of the Columbian Exchange and its effect on Europe and the Americas during the period after 1492.

tags.label: Unit 1, Learning Objective E
tags.description: Unit 1, Learning Objective E: Explain how the growth of the Spanish Empire in North America shaped the development of social and economic structures over time.

tags.label: Unit 1, Learning Objective F
tags.description: Unit 1, Learning Objective F: Explain how and why European and Native American perspectives of others developed and changed in the period.

tags.label: Unit 1, Learning Objective G
tags.description: Unit 1, Learning Objective G: Explain the effects of the development of transatlantic voyages from 1491 to 1607.

tags.label: Unit 2, Learning Objective A
tags.description: Unit 2, Learning Objective A: Explain the context for the colonization of North America from 1607 to 1754.

tags.label: Unit 2, Learning Objective B
tags.description: Unit 2, Learning Objective B: Explain how and why various European colonies developed and expanded from 1607 to 1754.

tags.label: Unit 2, Learning Objective C
tags.description: Unit 2, Learning Objective C: Explain how and why environmental and other factors shaped the development and expansion of various British colonies that developed and expanded from 1607 to 1754.

tags.label: Unit 2, Learning Objective D
tags.description: Unit 2, Learning Objective D: Explain causes and effects of transatlantic trade over time.

tags.label: Unit 2, Learning Objective E
tags.description: Unit 2, Learning Objective E: Explain how and why interactions between various European nations and American Indians changed over time.

tags.label: Unit 2, Learning Objective F
tags.description: Unit 2, Learning Objective F: Explain the causes and effects of slavery in the various British colonial regions.

tags.label: Unit 2, Learning Objective G
tags.description: Unit 2, Learning Objective G: Explain how enslaved people responded to slavery.

tags.label: Unit 2, Learning Objective H
tags.description: Unit 2, Learning Objective H: Explain how and why the movement of a variety of people and ideas across the Atlantic contributed to the development of American culture over time.

tags.label: Unit 2, Learning Objective I
tags.description: Unit 2, Learning Objective I: Explain how and why the different goals and interests of European leaders and colonists affected how they viewed themselves and their relationship with Britain.

tags.label: Unit 2, Learning Objective J
tags.description: Unit 2, Learning Objective J: Compare the effects of the development of colonial society in the various regions of North America.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective A
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective A : Explain the context in which America gained independence and developed a sense of national identity.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective B
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective B: Explain the causes and effects of the Seven Years' War (the French and Indian War).

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective C
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective C: Explain how British colonial policies regarding North America led to the Revolutionary War.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective D
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective D: Explain how and why colonial attitudes about government and the individual changed in the years leading up to the American Revolution.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective E
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective E: Explain how various factors contributed to the American victory in the Revolution.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective F
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective F: Explain the various ways the American Revolution affected society.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective G
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective G: Describe the global impact of the American Revolution.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective H
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective H: Explain how different forms of government developed and changed as a result of the Revolutionary Period.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective I
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective I: Explain the differing ideological positions on the structure and function of the federal government

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective J
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective J: Explain the continuities and changes in the structure and functions of the government with the ratification of the Constitution.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective K
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective K: Explain how and why competition intensified conflicts among peoples and nations from 1754 to 1800.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective L
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective L: Explain how and why political ideas, institutions, and party systems developed and changed in the new republic.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective M
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective M: Explain the continuities and changes in American culture from 1754 to 1800.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective N
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective N: Explain how and why migration and immigration to and within North America caused competition and conflict over time.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective O
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective O: Explain the continuities and changes in regional attitudes about slavery as it expanded from 1754 to 1800.

tags.label: Unit 3, Learning Objective P
tags.description: Unit 3, Learning Objective P: Explain how the American independence movement affected society from 1754 to 1800.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective A
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective A: Explain the context in which the republic developed from 1800 to 1848.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective B
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective B: Explain the causes and effects of policy debates in the early republic.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective C
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective C: Explain how different regional interests affected debates about the role of the federal government in the early republic.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective D
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective D: Explain how and why American foreign policy developed and expanded over time.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective E
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective E: Explain the causes and effects of the innovations in technology, agriculture, and commerce over time.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective F
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective F: Explain how and why innovation in technology, agriculture, and commerce affected various segments of American society over time.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective G
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective G: Explain the causes and effects of the expansion of participatory democracy from 1800 to 1848.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective H
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective H: Explain the causes and effects of continuing policy debates about the role of the federal government from 1800 to 1848.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective I
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective I: Explain how and why a new national culture developed from 1800 to 1848.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective J
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective J: Explain the causes of the Second Great Awakening.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective K
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective K: Explain how and why various reform movements developed and expanded from 1800 to 1848.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective L
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective L: Explain the continuities and changes in the experience of African Americans from 1800 to 1848.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective M
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective M: Explain how geographic and environmental factors shaped the development of the South from 1800 to 1848.

tags.label: Unit 4, Learning Objective N
tags.description: Unit 4, Learning Objective N: Explain the extent to which politics, economics, and foreign policy promoted the development of American identity from 1800 to 1848.

tags.description: Unit 5, Learning Objective A: Explain the context in which sectional conflict emerged from 1844 to 1877.

tags.description: Unit 5, Learning Objective B: Explain the causes and effects of westward expansion from 1844 to 1877.

tags.description: Unit 5, Learning Objective C: Explain the causes and effects of the Mexican-American War.

tags.label: Unit 5, Learning Objective M
tags.description: Unit 5, Learning Objective M: Compare the relative significance of the effects of the Civil War on American values.

tags.description: Unit 6, Learning Objective A: Explain the historical context for the rise of industrial capitalism in the United States.

tags.description: Unit 6, Learning Objective F: Explain how cultural and economic factors affected migration patterns over time.

tags.label: Unit 6, Learning Objective G

tags.description: Unit 6, Learning Objective H: Explain the causes of increased economic opportunity and its effects on society.

tags.label: Unit 6, Learning Objective L
tags.description: Unit 6, Learning Objective L: Explain the extent to which industrialization brought change from 1865 to 1898.

tags.label: ARC
tags.description: ARC: Creative expression, demographic change, philosophy, religious beliefs, scientific ideas, social mores, and technology shape national, regional, and group cultures in America, and these varying cultures often play a role in shaping government policy and developing economic systems.

tags.label: GEO
tags.description: GEO: Geographic and environmental factors, including competition over and debates about natural resources, shape the development of America and foster regional diversity. The development of America impacts the environment and reshapes geography, which leads to debates about environmental and geographic issues.

tags.label: MIG
tags.description: MIG: Push and pull factors shape immigration to and migration within America, and the demographic change as a result of these moves shapes the migrants, society, and the environment.

tags.label: NAT
tags.description: NAT: The development of and debates about democracy, freedom, citizenship, diversity, and individualism shape American national identity, cultural values, and beliefs about American exceptionalism, and in turn, these ideas shape political institutions and society. Throughout American history, notions of national identity and culture have coexisted with varying degrees of regional and group identities.

tags.label: PCE
tags.description: PCE: Debates fostered by social and political groups about the role of government in American social, political, and economic life shape government policy, institutions, political parties, and the rights of citizens.

tags.label: SOC
tags.description: SOC: Social categories, roles, and practices are created, maintained, challenged, and transformed throughout American history, shaping government policy, economic systems, culture, and the lives of citizens.

tags.label: WOR
tags.description: WOR: Diplomatic, economic, cultural, and military interactions between empires, nations, and peoples shape the development of America and America's increasingly important role in the world.

tags.label: WXT
tags.description: WXT: The interplay between markets, private enterprise, labor, technology, and government policy shape the American economy. In turn, economic activity shapes society and government policy and drives technological innovation.
